Fields.DialogueText: Ah, nothing feels better than the open air when you're ready for a brand new quest. Crew, let's prepare to move out.
Wait just a minute! I must've misheard you!
Rawalpindi, there you are.
Were you seriously about to set off without consulting me first?

Fields.MenuText: My apologies, I may have gotten a little swept up in the moment.
I'm the captain of this ship, Rawalpindi. I'm not required to consult with you each time we make way.
Maybe next time you won't be tardy.

Fields.DialogueText: It'd be an excellent idea for you to remember next time.
You may be the captain, but let's not forget that I am the ship.
Tardy?! How do you know I wasn't busy keeping this ship afloat or something, hmmm?
The important part is that you're here now. We're finally ready to embark on our next journey.
I can't wait. Those Morganas won't know what's hit them!
You know this isn't going to be easy, right?
I'm sure I can handle it. I may not have been made for war like most of the other Belles, but that doesn't mean you should underestimate me.
I'm sure we'll have an opportunity to see what you're made of soon enough.
That opportunity can't come soon enough.
@BATTLE
This is quite the ship, Rawalpindi. You're clearly well-traveled.
Before I was requisitioned for the war, I was a merchant vessel. That doesn't mean I'm not ready to fight, though!
I didn't mean to imply anything else. I've seen the effort you put into taking care of your guns.
You've noticed? Yes, I make sure my arsenal is clean and ready for battle at all times.
They're certainly clean, but they do look a bit... outdated.
They date back to the Great War, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Why would you be using guns older than you?
I'll keep my fingers crossed that they keep working.
We can't have you using these relics.

Fields.DialogueText: When they repurposed me for the war, they armed me with what they could. They're more effective than they look.
They may be old, but I know how to use them. You'll see soon enough.
Haven't you heard, Captain? It's not the weapon, but the Belle behind the trigger.
These guns have already helped to end one war. They'll serve us in this one just as well.
Hmmm... The fleet is only as strong as its weakest link, Rawalpindi.
And you believe me to be that weak link?
Do you?
*ALARM*
Not in the slightest. But if you need more proof, I'll gladly keep destroying Morganas until you see how strong I am.
@BATTLE
Captain, there haven't been any Morganas sighted recently, have there?
Not that I'm aware of. Looking for a fight, Rawalpindi?
You could say that. It's not that I'm rash, I've just never had an opportunity like this. Most merchant vessels don't fight for their country, but I want to make the most of it.

Fields.MenuText: I like your attitude. Give it some time and we'll have more Morganas than we'll know what to do with.
You do understand that solving this conflict with as little violence as possible would be preferable, right?
You're not at all unnerved by your lack of experience?

Fields.DialogueText: That's an easy one, we'll destroy them.
Obviously, but if there wasn't any violence, this would hardly be a war, now would it?
I may be inexperienced, Captain, but so is everyone when they first start out. Fighting Morganas is how I'll gain experience.
There's no rush, so while we've got some downtime I suggest you grab something to eat, maybe enjoy the weather a little. Just relax.
*ALARM*
You were saying?
I was saying there wasn't a rush. There is now, though.
Don't worry, Captain. I'll have this finished before you can even blink.
I'm ready to be impressed, Rawalpindi.
@BATTLE
Do you ever feel... left out?
What do you mean, Captain?
Your guns. All the other ships have new, improved artillery, and you're stuck with yesterday's model.
I don't think of it like that. I've actually grown to like these old guns.

Fields.MenuText: But they're on their last legs. Aren't some of them barely holding together?
Still, we should probably look into getting you some new guns.
You do keep them in great shape.

Fields.DialogueText: They're actually in remarkable condition. I think you'd be surprised how good a shape they're all in.
That's simply not necessary, Captain. I'm sure there are a number of things that could utilize the funds.
Thank you for noticing, Captain. I'm glad you can appreciate hard work.
Old or not, the important part is that they can still tear apart a Morgana.
You're right. There are a lot of things we don't know about Morganas, but we know our artillery can take them on.
It is curious though, isn't it? What they are, what they want, why they're here? So many questions about these Morganas, and so few answers.
*ALARM*
Unfortunately we don't have the time to be asking questions.
There will be time for questions once we emerge victorious.
I admire your optimistic spirit, Rawalpindi.
@BATTLE
Captain, we've got more trouble up ahead.
Not more Morganas...
No... it looks to be a German ship, Captain.
A German ship? What are they doing all the way out here?
Getting in our way, apparently.

Fields.MenuText: Be nice. They're better than Morganas.
You have a problem with Germans?
I'm not the biggest fan of them either.

Fields.DialogueText: I have not forgotten the Zurich agreement, Captain. At least we can blow up Morganas without setting off an international incident.
I have a problem with anyone standing in my way.
I'm sure they'd have a few pointed words for us as well.
Remember, Rawalpindi, we have an international crew aboard this ship. You wouldn't want a member of the crew getting the wrong idea.
I don't have anything specific against Germany. I mean besides the obvious. I'm just not exactly the most patient person, and this ship is keeping us from moving onward.
*ALARM*
Well, look at that. Yesterday's blockade might be today's ally.
Perhaps. If I leave any for them to finish off.
@BATTLE
Captain? What do you think about this temporary truce we've built between the Axis and the Allies?
I think it's the only reason the Morganas haven't killed us all.
Yes, you're probably right. But what do you think will happen after the Morganas are dealt with? Do you believe we'll be able to find peace?

Fields.MenuText: After facing an enemy like the Morganas? Yes, I think it's possible.
I don't think so. I think we'll pick things back up right where we left them.
I don't know. What do I look like, a politician?

Fields.DialogueText: It's good to be positive. Especially for the sake of the crew.
Disappointing. You'd think the nations would take this opportunity to realize the power they'd have if they came together.
You really have no interest? I suppose you're a soldier through and through. I can respect that.
What brought all this up, Rawalpindi?
As a merchant, you think about the future a lot. Your next destination, upcoming jobs, how much you're going to charge.
I have less to think about with my new profession, but my mind is still racing, worried about what will happen if an end to this war never comes.
A war makes everybody question the future.
So there's no easy answer? That's not what I was hoping to hear.
I'm sure it wasn't. Sorry I couldn't be more help.
*ALARM*
About time. I'm done worrying for now. I need to destroy something. I need to feel like I'm making some progress toward ending at least one of these wars.
You've got some fire in you.
You haven't seen anything yet.
@BATTLE
So, Captain, what do you think? How have I handled myself in battle? Better than you expected?
You're certainly a natural. If I didn't know better, I'd swear you've been fighting for years.
Flattery will get you everywhere with me! I didn't exactly start from square one, though.
I spent a great deal of time ferrying folk across the Atlantic. I know it far better than any Morganas could.
I knew you were a merchant vessel, but I didn't realize you transported people.
Merchandise can mean a number of things, Captain. I also worked as a mail carrier at times if you must know.
Rest assured though, I'm not pining for my old career. I'm overjoyed to be fighting to protect my country.
I'm sure you were great at delivering mail, Rawalpindi, but you belong in this fleet.
I was, and I do. Thank you, Captain.
Oh, speaking of mail, has ours come yet?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, it has. I don't think you got anything though.
Not yet. Expecting something?
Actually, it's been some time since we received any mail.

Fields.DialogueText: That's okay. It's just nice to know that our mail carrier is doing their job.
No, I'm not expecting anything. Though I am disappointed. War makes deliveries difficult, but they still need to be done.
Really? Someone clearly isn't doing their job. How exasperating.
You know, you shouldn't really be worrying about the mail anymore.
*ALARM*
Obviously. I clearly have bigger things to worry about.
@BATTLE
Rawalpindi, is this your book here?
Oh! Yes, that one is mine. I don't know how I could forget it.
"The Influence of Sea Power upon History"? Good choice if you don't mind my saying.
It really is. It must be my favorite book! I've read it a dozen times.
A dozen times? And you're not bored of it?
How could I be? It's part history and part introspection. It details how Britain became as strong as it now is, and why the sea is so important.
Of course I can't get enough of its detailed historical naval battles and how they were won. I find the whole work... enthralling.

Fields.MenuText: Are you an avid reader?
Well, just try better not to lose it again, okay?
Never read it myself, but that's a stellar recommendation.

Fields.DialogueText: Not usually, but I make an exception for this book specifically.
Of course, Captain. I'll be more careful. I wouldn't want to lose my good luck charm.
I'd let you borrow mine, but it's grown to be a bit of a good luck charm for me. You should pick up your own copy when you get the chance.
It'll have to be the next thing I read.
You won't regret it. Each time I read it, there's something new for me to learn.
Are you saying I have a lot to learn?
Ha, look at that! Quite perceptive of you to read between the lines.
@BATTLE
Rawalpindi, have you grown close with anybody on the ship?
I would like to think that I've made friends with everyone.
Everyone? That's impressive.
You don't believe me?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I don't. You're a big ship, and there's no way you've made friends with everyone.
I didn't say that.
No, I believe you. You have no reason to lie to me.

Fields.DialogueText: And now you're calling me a big fat liar? Classy, Captain, very classy... though I will admit to some exaggeration.
You didn't have to. I could tell what you meant.
Ugh, now I can't tell if you're being sincere or even more sarcastic.
If you must know, I've only talked with a handful of British officers onboard. We had some mutual friends.
What do you mean mutual friends?
Well, during my time transporting people back and forth between London and Bombay, I carried some of our officers friends and family members.
I suppose it's a small world.
Yes, it truly is sometimes, isn't it?
Try and talk with more of the crew if you can, Rawalpindi. I want you to know who exactly you're fighting for.
*ALARM*
I know who we're fighting for, Captain. More importantly I know what we're fighting against. The Morganas just want to destroy everyone and everything on this world. I won't have it.
Neither will I. Let's go.
@BATTLE
I find it interesting that your favorite book was written by an American.
You think it's odd?
Not quite odd. Just... interesting. Other than your choice of reading, there's nothing else American about you at all.
You act as if Belles are only allowed to be interested in their own country of origin.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry. That's not quite what I meant.
Some Belles are quite nationalistic.
Forgive me, I'm still wrapping my head around this "ship spirit" thing.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not upset, Captain, just choose your words more carefully in the future.
There are as many different kinds of Belles as there are people. I would've thought you'd understand that.
I suppose I can understand.
I might have to start taking lessons from you, Rawalpindi. Think you can teach me a thing or two about Belle etiquette?
You'd be better off asking another Belle. Etiquette isn't exactly my strong suit.
*ALARM*
I'm guessing you consider destroying Morganas your strong suit?
Naturally, Captain.
@BATTLE
I may have noticed that.
I could really use a drink right about now.
Hmm? What is it, Captain? Is something wrong?
Keeping up with supply issues, mechanical casualties, and constant attacks... It adds up sometimes.
That sounds like a war on all fronts, but you're not in it alone. You've got me to help.
You're right. Thanks, Rawalpindi.
Just tell me what needs our attention most urgently.

Fields.MenuText: We should probably start with the Morganas.
We need supplies to keep fighting. Resupplying has to take priority.
We should tour the engine room. We don't want to break down, right?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll radio command and let them know we're on our way.
Not a problem, Captain. I will ensure supplies are rationed until our next port call. We'll be fine.
That's something I can handle on my own. Give me a moment to ensure our machinery is in good condition. You will have my report of any pressing issues I find.
Thanks, Rawalpindi. I appreciate the assistance.
I am also here to support you and your efforts, Captain.
Hmmm, maybe you got that from being a transport ship for so long. You wanted to make sure your passengers were taken care of.
Perhaps. Or maybe I just like you.
*ALARM*
And how do you like these Morganas?
I like them better in pieces.
@BATTLE
Another pack of Morganas inbound, Rawalpindi.
We know what to do.
@BATTLE
The Morganas are running, Captain! We must pursue at flank speed!
Rawalpindi? You've got a... bloodlust in your eyes.
We can destroy them! Listen to me. They always retreat and recover... but if we pursue, we could completely eviscerate them!
Negative, Rawalpindi. We have our standing orders from command. We can't just leave our post while we're needed here.
But the Morganas---!
Could be luring us into a trap, or trying to draw our attention away from a bigger threat.
Remember telling me you were always thinking about the future? Keep the long view in mind.
You're... making sense. I'm sorry, I... I got a little too focused on the fight there.

Fields.MenuText: You looked like a madwoman.
Are you okay?
Honestly, I liked the energy. Just keep it focused on the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Did I really? I hope I didn't scare you.
I'm... fine. I'm more worried about you.
You liked it? I'll stop holding it back as much then.
I know I got a little intense there. I just wasn't ready for the battle to end.
You looked like you were on the verge of going berserk.
Berserk is a strong word. I prefer determined. But yes. I think it's part of what makes me such a good soldier.
I can't disagree, but you still have to follow my orders. And I think we need to wait for word from command before leaving our post.
I understand. You won't get any arguments from me.
Rawalpindi, I could use some assistance with navigation.
Sounds like you're lost. How can I help?
Are you familiar with the waters around here?
That depends. I've spent very little time in the southern hemisphere.
I thought you knew the Atlantic like the back of your hand.
The North Atlantic, yes. My routes beyond that region, however, were limited. The southern Atlantic waters are more like the back of my... ankle, maybe.

Fields.MenuText: I guess merchants aren't really much for exploring.
Traveling the same routes over and over again? Sounds boring.
So you've got an impressive knowledge of half the Atlantic? You're suddenly half as impressive.

Fields.DialogueText: No, they usually stick to efficient routes and whatever makes them a tidy profit.
I can't say I was ever bored. However, I did sometimes long to branch out and explore more.
Half as impressive you say? Well, that's still twice as impressive as you are. You're the one asking for navigation help, remember?
I've been working to expand my knowledge of the Atlantic. I should get my notes; they'd help.
Hurry, please. If we sit out here too long, Morganas are bound to-
*BOOM*
Show up?
Yeah... show up.
@BATTLE
Rawalpindi, there's a letter for you in the post.
I wonder how long ago it was sent. If it's dated too far back, I might have to get someone fired.
Heh, no one needs to lose their job because you have a superhuman work ethic.
Hmm... No... No. No. This isn't... No!
What's wrong? What's in the letter?
Idiocy. Unbelievable stupidity. A friend of mine, another Belle, claims that there's talk of making me a transport vessel again.
They want to take you off the front lines?
And out of battle, yes. If this letter is to be believed.

Fields.MenuText: No, I'd know about something like that.
If it's true, we just need to remind them how vital you are in your current position.
Ultimately, we'll have to fall in line with whatever is decided.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe your own message was lost in the mail. Someone should be fired if that's the case.
We shouldn't have to do that! Haven't I proven to be a worthy soldier? I've defeated just as many Morganas as any other Belle.
Thanks for the support...
What do you want to do about this, Rawalpindi?
What do you think I want to do? I want to destroy each and every Morgana plaguing this planet. I can't do that as a glorified ferry!
You're a critical asset, Rawalpindi. I'll do everything that I can to keep you fighting.
Thank you, Captain.
Let's just hope it's enough.
@BATTLE
Rawalpindi, I'm drafting a letter to send to command. I'd like some information from you before I send it.
Anything to keep me in the fight. Ask whatever questions you have.
I'm looking for some input on my letter to HQ. Why do you want to fight?
Because I can make a difference, and I do. I may not have been designed for war, but I've proven myself in battle.
I'd rather serve by destroying Morganas on the battlefield, not shuffling cargo and people to and fro.
Well said, Rawalpindi.
I think I have what I need. I just wish we could go to them in person. With passion like that, they wouldn't think twice about keeping you in the battle.
Stop making me happy when I'm trying to be angry.

Fields.MenuText: We'll get through to them. I'm sure of it.
Be ready for the worst. Just in case.
I'll send off this letter, and then it's up to fate.

Fields.DialogueText: I wish I had your confidence.
Great, so neither of us think this will work? I'm doomed.
Let's hope fate is on my side.
*ALARM*
Look at that, the perfect opportunity to prove how invaluable you are.
More like the perfect opportunity to blow off some steam. Let's riddle the waters with hunks of Morgana.
@BATTLE
I've sent the letter advocating to keep us on the front lines, Rawalpindi. The deed has been done.
I suppose we've done all we can then. They'll read the letter, make their decision, and that will be that.

Fields.MenuText: Are you nervous? I think we should be nervous.
Is there nothing else we can do?
Don't worry too much. We'll be fine.

Fields.DialogueText: Let's focus on our work. That's all we can do until we receive word back.
I think not. Sending more letters. would probably just annoy them.
Easier said than done... but I'm sure you're right. I've proven myself. I'm meant to fight!
*ALARM*
Morganas?
Seems like they're itching for a fight.
We don't have to wait for orders to engage them this time?
They're not that far from our post. Come on, let's notch one more victory on our belts.
You make it sound like it'll be our last. I refuse to stop fighting!
@BATTLE
Captain, a group of Morganas are mobilizing towards our position!
Guns ready, Rawalpindi?
You know I keep my weapons in perfect working order.
Then we're ready as always. Why do you sound worried?
Just eager for a fight, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: That's what I like to hear.
You better be sure, Rawalpindi.
Hmmm... maybe we should just play it safe and withdraw from this one.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll show them we're more than a merchant with some peashooters.
I'm positive, Captain. I can't afford to lose now.
Retreat? I won't allow it. We have to at least try. We have a reputation to uphold!
*ALARM*
Looks like they're closing in. That... that is a pretty impressive formation of Morganas.
Don't be impressed. They'll be nothing but floating refuse when I'm finished with them.
I can't wait to see that. Let's not waste anymore time!
@BATTLE
More Morganas coming in from the south!
They just don't know when to give up!
There's that frenzied look in her eyes again.
@BATTLE
They just keep coming, Rawalpindi.
I know, isn't it great?! It's like they're lining up to fall!
Stay focused, Rawalpindi. I don't want you to get carried away.
What? I assure you, Captain, that I have everything under control.
*BOOM*
This pack seems better disciplined than previous Morganas we've faced. We don't want our pride to get the better of us.
But... I... I see. You might be right. A tactical retreat may be prudent.

Fields.MenuText: Now you're making sense.
There's nothing tactical about it. We need to run for our lives!
I just hope it's not too late for that.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I got lost in the battle again. My apologies.
This is no time to panic, Captain. We can't let the crew lose their nerve.
It's never too late. We'll make it out of this, Captain.
Look, there's an opening, Captain. We just need to put a little distance between us and our foes.
Good thing our engines are still operational. Steady as she goes, Rawalpindi.
Smart move. We'll get another chance, Rawalpindi. Don't get discouraged.
Aye aye, Captain.
*ALARM*
They're gaining on us, Captain.
Damn. We have no choice but to dispatch the ones nearest us.
Hmmm... There. After we take care of them we can hide behind that large rock.
You're sure that will work?
Trust me.
@BATTLE
It seems the sea has calmed. For the moment at least.
They'll return in time, but for now we can breathe easy.
With so much combat, I've almost forgotten about our other problem.
You mean my getting reassigned to transport duty? I don't suppose we've gotten a reply yet?
Not yet, Rawalpindi. To be honest, the lack of a reply doesn't bode well for us.
Well... we've had a good run, haven't we? A shame that our skillful evasion will probably go unnoticed by HQ.

Fields.MenuText: Don't give up on me just yet. Our run isn't over.
If it counts for anything, I was impressed.
We had a great run. I wish it could go on longer.

Fields.DialogueText: I never give up, Captain. Never.
I'm glad to leave you with such a memorable encounter.
As do I... but perhaps our time together really is coming to an end.
This isn't fair... You'll be wasted if they just have you transporting people. You're a fighter.
It means a lot that you think that, Captain. I'm afraid, however, that HQ sees little more than a merchant with some vintage weapons.
There's more to you than that though.
I... I'm glad that you can see that.
I see the mail has come. About time. Someone really is slacking on the job. It's like they have no sense!
HQ made their decision, Rawalpindi.
They did? And... what is my fate?
They intend to reassign you. Transporting people along the same routes you used to use before the war.
Back to a transport vessel? I shouldn't be so surprised. I was just holding out a little hope, I suppose.

Fields.MenuText: I wish things were different, but we have to follow orders.
I'm unhappy about all this too, Rawalpindi...
No. There has to be something we can do about this!

Fields.DialogueText: Do we? Orders can be wrong sometimes, Captain.
If we both disagree with this decision then let's do something about it!
What do you think about a little rebellion? Too far? Yeah, maybe...
Forgive me, Captain. I may be enthusiastic, but I'm not insubordinate. I will accept HQ's decision.
Rawalpindi...
When are they intending to take me away from the fight?
They didn't specify.
*ALARM*
Well, in that case. I still have Morganas to defeat. Care to join me for what could perhaps be my last battle?
@BATTLE
With pride.
I've made up my mind, Captain.
So have I.
Well, I said it first, so let me finish.
Assertive as ever, aren't you? Be my guest.
I refuse to be reassigned. I know what I said about insubordination, but I will openly defy our superiors if that's what it takes to stay out here fighting Morganas. With you.
What a coincidence, I was about to say the same thing.
Really? I... I didn't expect you to side with me in such an act of defiance. Aren't you worried about being reprimanded?

Fields.MenuText: I'm more worried about fighting without you. I need you here.
Aren't you?
You're right... Maybe I should just let them reassign you.

Fields.DialogueText: That's one more thing we see eye to eye on. You do need me here.
I'm a Belle, it's not like they can demote me or anything.
Captain, don't even joke like that. I heard what you said.
So, should I assume you have some sort of plan?
Um... not really, I hadn't thought it through beyond just telling them no. Repeatedly.
I like your candor, but we might need something more.
Such as?
*ALARM*
We can figure that out after we take care of these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Captain, the mail has arrived. This letter is for you.
I'm not expecting good news. Maybe I should just toss it overboard.
Your instincts are correct. The letter is a reprimand from HQ for insubordination.
Wait, you opened my mail?!
I grew tired of waiting for you to read it. Also, I've already sent a reply on your behalf.
I'm scared to ask... but what did you say to HQ?
I told them I wouldn't allow you to be taken away from the battle. They needed to find another ship to use as transport, or else.

Fields.MenuText: "Or else"? Disagreeing with HQ is one thing, but threatening them?

Fields.DialogueText: You think I went too far. I suppose we have different opinions on the matter.
Good.
So what do we do now? What's our next step?
Well, they still haven't issued any official order to reassign you yet. We keep fighting Morganas and prove to them that you belong out here.
You think they'll see past my... differences?
When I first stepped aboard, I saw you as a repurposed merchant vessel with a few outdated guns. Now I know you're more than that.
You're nothing if not a warship. It took me time to understand that. HQ will see it, too.
I'm not sure whether I should be flattered or insulted.
I recommend flattered. For my sake.
@BATTLE
I meant no disrespect, Captain. In the future, I will... consult with you on matters like this.

Fields.MenuText: Good work. You must have read my mind.
I like your initiative, but you should talk to me about things like this first.

Fields.DialogueText: I've learned a thing or two about you by now!
What's done is done.
Heavy Morgana presence in our area lately... Rawalpindi, think the Morganas are coming after us?
Our reputation must be growing. I knew the Morganas would learn to respect me!
That respect comes at a price. Eventually we might get overwhelmed by sheer numbers.
I've been thinking about that actually. For centuries, the British Navy utilized coves and inlets along the coast. They made perfect hiding spots.
So you're suggesting we launch a sneak attack?
I'm suggesting we use our environment to our advantage. If we do this properly, we can decimate a huge portion of the horde before they realize what's happened.

Fields.MenuText: I'm assuming you read about this in your favorite book, correct?
It's something we haven't tried at least.
Coves and inlets, huh? I'm not so sure.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. I learn something new with every read through.
A little trust, Captain. Centuries of victory can't be wrong.
Give me a chance to convince you! That's all I ask.
Okay, lets try your plan, Rawalpindi.
Thank you, Captain. Here, I've already marked a few spots on the map I thought might work for my plan.
*ALARM*
Looks like we have some trouble to deal with first.
True. We can't exactly hide if there are Morganas on our tail.
@BATTLE
This is the cove, huh? It's nice. Very cozy.
I suppose. More importantly it'll keep us out of sight from the Morganas.
Speaking of Morganas. You're sure they're nearby?
Yes. They're about to pass our location. As soon as their rears our in our sights, that's when we blow them to pieces.

Fields.MenuText: Anything to get some of these Morganas off our backs...
This better work...
I can't wait to shove a victory in HQ's faces.

Fields.DialogueText: Beating this group might should deliver a strong message to other Morganas that we're not to be trifled with.
It will or it won't. Either way... I'd rather fall to Morganas than give up the fight.
This will no doubt change their minds. They'll have to see me for the fighter I am.
You know what... this will work. I just have a feeling.
A feeling? That's all you've got?
It's all I need.
*ALARM*
They're passing us now. Let's hope your feeling is right.
It is. Prepare for battle! We strike after they pass!
@BATTLE
I still can't believe we did it, Captain. That was an amazing battle!
We only came out on top because of your idea. This is why we need you fighting the Morganas.
Don't tell me that. Tell the people deciding my fate.
I did. And this is how they responded.
What? Another letter?
It came pretty quickly. They must've been impressed.
"In light of recent events and an exemplary show of courage, we have reconsidered our previous position."
This says I can continue to fight. I don't have to be a transport ship again.
They finally saw past the surface... to see the bloodthirsty soldier underneath.
"Bloodthirsty"?! I'll admit to "zeal" or "excessive focus" in battle at times, but...
You get heated in the middle of battle, Rawalpindi. Few other Belle's have that sort of intensity, and it can be intimidating.
Are you saying you're afraid of me?

Fields.MenuText: A little bit, but in a good way.
Of course not. I'm far scarier than you.

Fields.DialogueText: A good way? That sounds interesting. You'll have to elaborate some time.
You? Scary? I just can't see it.
